title: Bilateral Mixed Hearing Loss with Chronic Middle Ear Pathology
chief_complaint: I've had hearing loss in my left ear for 20 years after a cyst was removed. About 3 years ago, my right ear started getting worse too. I currently have a tube in the right ear, but I still feel pain and pressure there sometimes.

problem_summary.onset: Left ear 20 years ago; Right ear 3 years ago.
problem_summary.course: Left ear stable/long-standing; Right ear fluctuating with frequent fluid and tube extrusions.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Pain and pressure in the right ear; intermittent bilateral tinnitus.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Uses a hearing aid in the left ear occasionally; reports decreased hearing in the right ear.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Seeking management for right ear pain/hearing loss and monitoring of left ear.

history.present_illness: Patient reports a 20-year history of left ear hearing loss following cyst removal and infection. Right ear hearing decreased 3 years ago. Reports frequent fluid in the middle ear. Currently has a tube in the right ear but reports pain and pressure.
history.otologic_history: Left ear: Cyst removal 20 years ago, infection, failed surgical repair. Right ear: Multiple PE tubes placed (often fell out); current tube in place.
history.medical_psych_history: Denied dizziness. No family history of hearing loss.
history.prior_management: Occasional hearing aid use in the left ear.
history.patient_goals: Address right ear pain/pressure and hearing status.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear: Moderate mixed hearing loss, rising to normal at 2000 Hz, then sloping to severe sensorineural loss. Left ear: Severe mixed hearing loss with a profound mixed notch at 3000-4000 Hz. Significant air-bone gaps present bilaterally.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: SRT scores align with PTA. Word recognition scores are excellent bilaterally despite the degree of loss.

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.key_findings: Flat tympanograms (Type B) with large ear canal volumes bilaterally, consistent with patent PE tubes or perforation/surgical cavity.

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.key_findings: Absent ipsilateral and contralateral reflexes from 500 to 4000 Hz bilaterally. Decay could not be measured.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with bilateral mixed hearing loss. The left ear shows a severe-to-profound mixed loss (sequelae of previous cyst/surgery), while the right ear exhibits a moderate mixed loss rising to normal in the mid-frequencies before sloping to severe. Speech recognition remains excellent bilaterally. Immittance testing confirms large ear canal volumes consistent with the history of PE tubes and surgical intervention.
counseling_points: Referral to ENT is necessary to manage the active infection/pain in the right ear and check the status of the PE tube.
Continue using the hearing aid in the left ear as it provides benefit.
Once the right ear is medically cleared by the ENT, a hearing aid evaluation is recommended for the right ear to balance hearing.
Explanation of 'mixed' hearing loss: a combination of permanent nerve loss and mechanical issues (middle ear fluid/damage).
notes_for_actor: Portray a male patient, approx 54 years old.
You have a long history of ear surgeries on the left, but now the right ear is bothering you with pain and pressure.
You are frustrated that tubes keep falling out of your ears.
You deny any dizziness or noise exposure.
